abstract.p: Andrew Karmen letter comments on Aug 2 article on recruiting freshmen for City University of New York

block.p: Re ''College Takes to Street to Drum Up Enrollment'' (news article, Aug. 2): One overlooked factor that hampers the City University of New York's campaign to recruit more incoming freshmen is the perception of more difficult entrance requirements, and the improved job market for high school graduates.

Re ''College Takes to Street to Drum Up Enrollment'' (news article, Aug. 2): One overlooked factor that hampers the City University of New York's campaign to recruit more incoming freshmen is the perception of more difficult entrance requirements, and the improved job market for high school graduates.

The number of people between the ages of 20 and 24 living in the five boroughs declined from about 577,000 in 1990 to 471,000 in 1998, according to data compiled by the New York City Department of City Planning. This shortfall of potential new recruits not only makes it difficult to fill college classes, but also helps to account for the drop in street crime.
The writer is a professor of sociology at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, CUNY.
